te:
>
> Hi Joe,

> Joe Schmetzer wrote:
> >
> > >I've just updated the JU=
nit Anti-patterns page I maintain at
> > >http://www.exubero.com/junit/anti=
patterns.html. I'd be interested in
> > >any feedback, if people want to su=
ggest additions or improvements.

[snip multi-assert arguments already answ=
ered by David] 

> Also, it seems to me your recommended pattern for code t=
hat must
throw an
> exception ("don't catch it and declare the exception in=
 the throws
> statement") goes against common practice.  Plus, it will caus=
e JUnit to
> report an Error instead of a Failure, although this distinctio=
n is
> thankfully going away with JUnit4.
> 
> A more common way to address=
 this problem is to catch the exception
and do a
> fail().

Hi C=E9dric,

I=
 would argue that explicitly calling fail is less useful than
propagating t=
he exception outside of the test method, mainly because
the stack trace is =
lost. I've been caught a number of times myself
when a test failed because =
of an unexpected exception, but it was
non-trivial to track down the line t=
hat caused the exception. The
stack trace will show this information direct=
ly, any good JUnit test
runners will display the stack trace. IDEs will eve=
n take you to the
line of code, as well.

Therefore I think the advice in t=
he anti-patterns article regarding
exceptions is sound.

> Other than that,=
 your guide is fine advice.

Thanks!
